Description: Fragment of lip, body, handle root, and ring foot (mended from nine fragments) of South Ionian pottery cup with everted rim; interior: glazed black (partly worn); added red bands lined in white on inside of lip, at mid-wall and on edge of floor; exterior: lip and top of handle zone glazed; band below handle zone; added red and white lines on these; roughly painted band at bottom of wall and outside of low ring foot; underside reserved; modern drill hole on the handle.
Type series: Vallet and Villard Ionian Cup Type B1
Curator's comments: Schlotzhauer identifies this sherd as coming from a Type 10.2.A South Ionian cup with everted rim. Type 10 cups were mass produced and include numerous variants. These cups coincide with Hayes’ Ionian Cup Type V (Boardman and Hayes 1966, 111-6) and Vallet and Villard’s Ionian Cup Type B1 (Vallet and Villard, 1964, 87-8). Numerous Type 10 South Ionian cups have been found at Naukratis, as well as in the Sanctuary of Demeter and Kore at Tocra and at Megara Hyblaea on Sicily, and at Berezan on the Black Sea (Posamentir 2006, 165). The cup was analysed by Hans Mommsen, Bonn, with NAA and the fabric was placed in Group DD (very likely Miletus). Schlotzhauer previously published the sherd as belonging to Type 10,2.B (Schlotzhauer & Villing 2006, 55, Table 1).
Bibliographic references: Schlotzhauer & Villing 2006 / East Greek Pottery from Naukratis: The Current State of Research (p. 60, fig. 23, Table 1 Nauk 6)
Schlotzhauer 2012 / Untersuchungen zur archaischen griechischen Keramik aus Naukratis (p. 53, no. 336, p. 101-2, NAU 52, pl. 11)
Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. X, no. 12)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GE.692) (Phase 3)
